results.headline: Blasting Through the Dance Wars

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Battle of the Year 3D

results.summary_short: A bawdy college kegger has a possible extraterrestrial mystery in “+1.” The 3-D “Battle of the Year” has a dance team preparing for competition.

results.headline: A Loner Finds Bad Company

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Single Shot

results.summary_short: In “A Single Shot,” a loner living in a trailer finds — and throws himself into — a world of trouble when he has to deal with a dead woman and found cash.

results.headline: The Warrior as Nurturer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Arise

results.summary_short: “Arise” turns a lens on women battling environmental ills around the world.

results.headline: Heroes or Killers? Can We Try to Discuss?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of After Tiller

results.summary_short: The documentary “After Tiller” tells the story of four doctors who it says are the only ones in the United States openly performing third-trimester abortions.

results.headline: Love and Paranoia in Brooklyn: Yes, They Inhale. Repeatedly.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Newlyweeds

results.summary_short: In “Newlyweeds,” a man and a woman in Brooklyn love the pot they smoke as much as they love each other.

results.headline: The Woman Who Knew Too Much

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Enough Said

results.summary_short: Nicole Holofcener’s “Enough Said” stars Julia Louis-Dreyfus, James Gandolfini and Catherine Keener.

results.headline: A Descent Chronicled With Care

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of First Cousin Once Removed

results.summary_short: In “First Cousin Once Removed,” Alan Berliner looks at Edwin Honig’s life as Alzheimer’s took its toll.

results.headline: Trying to Be a Parent, for Better or for Worse

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mother of George

results.summary_short: “Mother of George,” Andrew Dosunmu’s new drama, is not only an assimilation story, but also a keenly observed tale of two people seeking guidance in painful and complicated circumstances.

results.headline: A Little Ditty That Became an Anthem of Hip-Hop

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sample This

results.summary_short: “Sample This,” from Dan Forrer, revisits the birth of hip-hop through “Apache,” by the Incredible Bongo Band.

results.headline: An All-Too-Human Federal Reserve
results.display_title: Money for Nothing: Inside the Federal Reserve

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Money for Nothing: Inside the Federal Reserve

results.summary_short: In the documentary “Money for Nothing,” Federal Reserve officials are shown as having great influence, if not great insights.

results.headline: Singing ‘Soprano’ in Normandy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Family

results.summary_short: Robert De Niro and Michelle Pfeiffer uproot their children and export their mobster ways to Normandy in “Family.”

results.headline: A Couple Flees a House of Death but Can’t Escape the Ghosts

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Insidious: Chapter 2

results.summary_short: “Insidious: Chapter 2” delves into a couple’s history and why they’re terrorized by ghosts.

results.headline: Microscope on the U.S. Food Supply

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of GMO OMG

results.summary_short: “GMO OMG,” a documentary from the director Jeremy Seifert, tries to inform viewers about food in America.

results.headline: The Activist Who Worked for the F.B.I.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Informant

results.summary_short: “Informant,” a profile of an activist who turned government informer, raises questions about identity and perspectives.

results.headline: In a Cultural and Sexual Netherland, Gaudy and Unsettling
results.display_title: The Last Time I Saw Macao

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Time I Saw Macao

results.summary_short: “The Last Time I Saw Macao,” a Portuguese-language film, explores the themes of contested territory and fragmentation.

results.headline: Sharing the Bounty of Priceless Art

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Herb & Dorothy 50x50

results.summary_short: “Herb & Dorothy 50x50” visits some of the museums given artworks from the Vogel collection.

results.headline: Silly Girl, You Want to Race a Boy?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wadjda

results.summary_short: Haifaa al-Mansour’s “Wadjda” is the story of a spirited 10-year-old Saudi girl discovering the severe limitations placed on women in the name of custom, Islam and family honor.

results.headline: Absolutely, Paul; Right Away, Ringo

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Good Ol' Freda

results.summary_short: “Good Ol’ Freda” chats with Freda Kelly, the onetime secretary for the Beatles, but she’s not dishing much.

results.headline: Seeking Connections on Independence Day

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Four

results.summary_short: “Four,” based on Christopher Shinn’s play, chronicles the assignations of two secretive for-a-night couples.

results.headline: A Strange Bond Between Killers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blue Caprice

results.summary_short: “Blue Caprice” recalls the terror of the Beltway sniper case but focuses on the father-son relationship of the murderers.
